intro: Carum buriaticum, commonly known as the Tibetan cumin, is a herbaceous plant native to the high altitudes of the Himalayas. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes other aromatic plants like parsley and dill. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its leaves are finely divided and have a distinctive, pungent aroma. Carum buriaticum is often used in traditional medicine for its purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties.
